channel.title: Nature Physics
channel.description: Nature Physics offers news and reviews alongside top-quality research papers in a monthly publication, covering the entire spectrum of physics. Physics addresses the properties and interactions of matter and energy, and plays a key role in the development of a broad range of technologies. To reflect this, Nature Physics covers all areas of pure and applied physics research. The journal focuses on core physics disciplines, but is also open to a broad range of topics whose central theme falls within the bounds of physics.

item.title: Optimal operation of hole spin qubits
item.content:encoded:
Nature Physics, Published online: 12 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41567-025-03106-1

Hole spin semiconductor qubits suffer from charge noise, but now it has been demonstrated that placing them in an appropriately oriented magnetic field can suppress this noise and improve qubit performance.
item.dc:title: Optimal operation of hole spin qubits
item.dc:creator: M. Bassi
E. A. Rodríguez-Mena
B. Brun
S. Zihlmann
T. Nguyen

S. De Franceschi
V. Schmitt

item.title: A super-conducting diode with ultimate efficiency and noise resilience at 77 K
item.content:encoded:
Nature Physics, Published online: 11 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41567-025-03118-x

An electrical method is shown to reliably introduce nonreciprocal behaviour across a Josephson junction made of high-temperature cuprate superconductors, which then, under microwave irradiation, forms a ‘quantum superconducting diode’. The device is magnetic-field-free, works at a temperature of 77 K with a diode efficiency of 100%, and, owing to Shapiro steps that quantize the output voltage, has robust noise-filtering.
item.dc:title: A super-conducting diode with ultimate efficiency and noise resilience at 77 K

item.title: Temporal anti-parity–time symmetry in diffusive transport
item.content:encoded:
Nature Physics, Published online: 10 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41567-025-03129-8

Applying concepts from non-Hermitian physics to diffusive systems enables the static control of heat transport. Now, this notion is expanded to dynamic control, including a demonstration of programmed thermal transport in a metamaterial.
item.dc:title: Temporal anti-parity–time symmetry in diffusive transport
item.dc:creator: Peng Jin
